entry.title: ITEM_20170516023
entry.itemBody: Which of the following financial intermediaries is most likely to provide liquidity service to its clients?

answerFeedback.472cb0bd-8e8f-489c-90bd-da01cbf28108: Correct. The service that dealers provide is liquidity. Liquidity is the ability to buy or sell with low transaction costs when investors want to trade. By allowing their clients to trade when they want to trade, dealers provide liquidity to them.
answerFeedback.917a8bdb-08c3-493a-b037-15991cb9c810: Incorrect. Exchanges provide places where traders and dealers can meet to arrange their trades.
answerFeedback.b5fa450f-19a5-44a1-a48b-d25bbaed8419: Incorrect. Brokers are agents who fill orders for their clients. They do not trade with their clients.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516048
entry.itemBody: An investor writes a put option on FTSE 100 Index futures. Which of the following best describes the investor’s position with respect to the put contract and her exposure to the underlying index future, respectively?

answerFeedback.6f72960d-4dd5-4be1-a89c-8a145d906a96: Incorrect. The investor has a short position in the put contract, not a long position, because she suffers a loss when the quoted price of the contract increases. The investor has a long exposure to the underlying index future, not a short position, because she benefits when its quoted price increases (or suffers a loss when its quoted price decreases).
answerFeedback.903df8b5-8d30-478e-b4d3-c1a62f396318: Incorrect. The investor has a long exposure to the underlying index future, not a short position, because she benefits when its quoted price increases (or suffers a loss when its quoted price decreases).
answerFeedback.c908f615-bf13-4cc6-9e9b-ce3223a2a6fa: Correct. The investor has written a put contract, which means she is short the option. She, therefore, must satisfy the obligation to purchase the asset if requested to do so by the put owner. The investor has a long exposure to the risk of the underlying index future because she benefits when its quoted price increases—that is, when the put declines in value (or suffers a loss when its quoted price decreases as the put increases in value).

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-01761
entry.itemBody: If securities are purchased on margin with a maximum leverage ratio of 1.75, the minimum margin requirement is closest to:

answerFeedback.3de73e9c-9b56-4938-b845-f04d857f8e2e: Correct because the maximum leverage ratio associated with a position financed by the minimum margin requirement is one divided by the minimum margin requirement. Or, MLR = 1 / MMR and MMR = 1 / MLR. In this case: the minimum margin requirement (MMR) = 1 / 1.75 = 57%.
answerFeedback.905994d3-076f-4130-8767-db0febf8db3d: Incorrect because it is (1 – the minimum margin requirement): 1 – (1 / 1.75) = 43%.
answerFeedback.dd241c77-5b54-442d-91fb-e8ec6e96be03: Incorrect because it is (the maximum leverage ratio – 1) = 1.75 – 1 = 75%.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B Equity 01SSI 03U3
entry.itemBody: When a company raises common equity capital in the public market, the company most likely:

answerFeedback.282197ed-f87e-4832-abaf-4162ae2507bc: Incorrect because when shareholders or partners contribute capital to a company, the company obtains money in the present in exchange for equity instruments that will be entitled to distributions in the future. The repayment of the money is not scheduled as it would be for loans.
answerFeedback.86e23368-bcaa-4dad-99c3-e7327ff2200a: Correct because when a company sells common stock to raise capital, regulatory reporting requirements and accounting standards attempt to ensure the production of meaningful financial disclosures.
answerFeedback.c81fbb70-56b7-4331-bedc-01483d1e1825: Incorrect because companies often raise money for projects by selling (issuing) ownership interests (e.g., corporate common stock or partnership interests). Although these equity instruments legally represent ownership in companies rather than loans to the companies, selling equity to raise capital is simply another mechanism for moving money from the future to the present.

choices.itemBody: A. moves money from the present to the future.
B. agrees to make scheduled distributions in the future.
C. is required to meet regulatory reporting requirements.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-Equity-Ermogenous-01
entry.itemBody:
A trader reports the following information about an equity investment which was sold after 1 year:

Number of shares purchased 2,000
Leverage ratio 3
Purchase price per share $12.00
Sale price per share $9.50
Call money rate per year 3%

The trader's equity value as a result of the trade is closest to:

answerFeedback.57071b17-c523-4d36-a507-3178f15a2eaf:
Incorrect because it uses the leverage ratio debt / equity invested instead of dividing the total equity investment by the leverage ratio.

The incorrect answer is calculated as follows:

Proceeds on sale – payoff amount borrowed – payoff loan interest

Amount paid to purchase shares = $12 × 2,000 = $24,000

Equity investment = $24,000/4 = $6,000

Amount borrowed = $24,000 – $6,000 = $18,000

Interest on loan = $18,000 × 3% = $540

Therefore, remaining equity = 2,000 × $9.5 – $18,000 – 3% × $18,000 = $19,000 – $18,000 – $540 = $460.
answerFeedback.689dfd3d-9961-4fe2-ad06-fbe3f1f0a7c9:
Correct because the remaining equity can be calculated as:

Proceeds on sale – payoff amount borrowed – payoff loan interest

Amount paid to purchase shares = $12 × 2,000 = $24,000

Equity investment = $24,000/3 = $8,000

Amount borrowed = $24,000 - $8,000 = $16,000

Interest on loan = $16,000 × 3% = $480

Therefore, remaining equity = 2,000 × $9.5 – $16,000 – 3% × $16,000 = $19,000 – $16,000 – $480 = $2,520.
answerFeedback.6c11f1bd-c4d6-45a9-b3da-e304bfbc889d:
Incorrect because payoff loan interest is omitted from the calculation of the trader's remaining equity.

Incorrect answer is calculated as follows:

Proceeds on sale – payoff amount borrowed

Amount paid to purchase shares = $12 × 2,000 = $24,000

Equity investment = $24,000/3 = $8,000

Amount borrowed = $24,000 – $8,000 = $16,000

Therefore, remaining equity = 2,000 × $9.5 – $16,000 = $19,000 – $16,000 = $3,000.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-Equity-Crutu-08
entry.itemBody: Order matching rules in order-driven trading systems are used to:

answerFeedback.ebf232c4-82c2-4a81-a5f3-692147045bde: Correct because the order matching rules match buy orders to sell orders.
answerFeedback.f4d8b936-1f44-4cea-a832-bf7954a5002a: Incorrect because the trade pricing rules (not the order matching rules) determine the prices at which the matched trades take place, regardless of who submits the order, the customer or the dealer.
answerFeedback.f6fd1ce2-1456-490e-9d0c-022b2f7f312a: Incorrect because the trade pricing rules (not the order matching rules) determine the prices at which the matched trades take place, regardless of who submits the order, the customer or dealer.

choices.itemBody: B. determine the prices at which the orders submitted by dealers are matched.
C. determine the prices at which the orders submitted by customers are matched.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-Equity-Crutu-01
entry.itemBody: A sell order that instructs the broker to obtain the best price immediately available without specifying a minimum price is a:

answerFeedback.70d76780-d9a6-47f4-aa95-62790a4583e3: Incorrect because a stop order is an order in which a trader has specified a stop price condition. The stop order may not be filled until the stop price condition has been satisfied. Stop-sell orders become valid when prices are falling and stop-buy orders become valid when prices are rising, in contrast with market orders which execute at the best price immediately available.
answerFeedback.7a7066c6-fee8-45dd-86a0-3494aea97474: Incorrect because in the case of a limit order, its execution depends on where the order is placed relative to the market price, as the broker will obtain the best price immediately available, but in no event accept a price higher than a specified limit price when buying or accept a price lower than a specified limit price when selling.
answerFeedback.f1f608d4-c2a4-467c-86b6-4ef53b45783f: Correct because a market order instructs the broker or exchange to obtain the best price immediately available when filling the order.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-Equity-Fairborn-02
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is an objective of market regulation?

answerFeedback.0a1e91bc-b20c-43c6-b176-6e79bd7e11c0:
Correct because the objectives of market regulation include both controlling agency problems and ensuring that long-term liabilities are funded.  In total, the objectives of market regulation are:

  1. control fraud.
  2. control agency problems.
  3. promote fairness.
  4. set mutually beneficial standards.
  5. prevent undercapitalized financial firms from exploiting their investors by making excessively risky investments; and
  6. ensure that long-term liabilities are funded.
answerFeedback.120a92d1-29e2-4b4d-bbc0-a25c0895f5c1: Incorrect because the objectives of market regulation are to control agency problems and ensure that long-term liabilities are funded. Therefore, an objective of market regulation is not to ensure that long-term liabilities are funded only.
answerFeedback.c8554620-4c88-4583-92c9-b5cffd0faf86: Incorrect because the objectives of market regulation are to control agency problems and ensure that long-term liabilities are funded. Therefore, an objective of market regulation is not to control agency problems only.

choices.itemBody: B. Ensuring that long-term liabilities are funded only
C. Both controlling agency problems and ensuring that long-term liabilities are funded

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-Equity-Kassem-01
entry.itemBody: If a European investor believes the US equity market will decline in the next three months, the transaction most likely to allow the investor to profit from this view is the purchase of a:

answerFeedback.67f23942-d7af-42b2-9578-ae611cb79620: Correct because option holders generally will exercise call options if the strike price is below the market price of the underlying instrument, in which case, they will be able to buy at a lower price than the market price. Similarly, they will exercise put options if the strike price is above the underlying instrument price so that they will sell at a higher price than the market price. Therefore, if the investor purchases a put option and the US market declines, they will profit by buying at the lower market price and selling at the higher strike price.
answerFeedback.7f5e9eee-44c3-42ef-bcb8-948e6aedbb97: Incorrect because option holders generally will exercise call options if the strike price is below the market price of the underlying instrument, in which case, they will be able to buy at a lower price than the market price. Similarly, they will exercise put options if the strike price is above the underlying instrument price so that they will sell at a higher price than the market price.
answerFeedback.9c120d35-e565-417c-96c8-dd8123a93889: Incorrect because a currency swap is a swap in which parties exchange payments denominated in different currencies. A currency swap will most likely not allow a European investor to profit from the decline in the US equity market.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-Equity-Grabe-02
entry.itemBody: When issuers sell securities to investors:

answerFeedback.1cc64257-13e4-4ce9-8321-160ce098c30f: Correct because when issuers sell securities to investors, practitioners say that they trade in the primary market.
answerFeedback.6d872350-c3c1-4597-ab53-2ba7bdc2d68e: Incorrect because when issuers sell securities to investors, practitioners say that they trade in the primary market. When investors sell those securities to others, they trade in the secondary market. In the primary market, funds flow to the issuer of the security from the purchaser. In the secondary market, funds flow between traders.
answerFeedback.ea80efbc-a438-4981-8868-bf3c8f75b14a: Incorrect because when issuers sell securities to investors, practitioners say that they trade in the primary market. When investors sell those securities to others, they trade in the secondary market.

choices.itemBody: A. they trade in the primary market.
B. they trade in the secondary market.
C. funds flow between the primary and the secondary market.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-RID-Bailey-Equity-008
entry.itemBody: If the price of a stock bought on 30% margin increases by 40%, the return on equity to the buyer is closest to:

answerFeedback.68cf380e-304b-4ea2-b8fc-cafb83e9e58b: Incorrect because it calculates return on equity as margin / return = 30%/40% = 75%. In other words, it incorrectly swaps the numerator and denominator in the correct solution (40%/30% becomes 30%/40%).
answerFeedback.969263a1-4091-41e8-a92c-bf954eafb8ea: Correct because the return on equity to a margin position is calculated by multiplying the unleveraged return by the financial leverage ratio. The financial leverage ratio is equal to 1/margin. In this case, financial leverage is 1/0.30 = 3.3333, so the return on equity = 40% × 3.3333 = 133.33%, which is closest to 133%.
answerFeedback.b9606bf4-b0bf-4cec-8ed5-7673d914cfa3: Incorrect because it calculates return on equity as unleveraged return × (1 + margin) = 40% × (1 + 30%) = 52%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Equity-Chan-08
entry.itemBody: In which markets are government bills most likely traded?

answerFeedback.6800dc07-9ec6-4f25-b198-cfd800e65375: Incorrect because capital markets trade instruments of longer duration, such as bonds and equities. Whereas government bills are a short-term debt instrument.
answerFeedback.6ad39406-4a7e-44d9-b32f-bcac7c32f739: Incorrect because alternative investments include hedge funds, private equities (including venture capital), commodities, real estate securities and real estate properties, securitized debts, operating leases, machinery, collectibles, and precious gems.
answerFeedback.f2094691-20db-4718-a4c6-2f5317c828d8: Correct because money markets trade debt instruments maturing in one year or less. The most common such instruments are repurchase agreements, negotiable certificates of deposit, government bills.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Equity-Zipp-13
entry.itemBody: Financial intermediaries that help their clients arrange seasoned securities offerings are best known as:

answerFeedback.2111771c-2b33-4c60-ab91-5c8157c315fd: Incorrect because depository institutions include commercial banks, savings and loan banks, credit unions, and similar institutions that raise funds from depositors and other investors and lend it to borrowers. The banks give their depositors interest and transaction services, such as check writing and check cashing, in exchange for using their money.
answerFeedback.3b271366-56d4-4a9e-b411-a425bd91b48c: Correct because investment banks provide advice to their mostly corporate clients and help them arrange transactions such as initial and seasoned securities offerings. Additionally, a seasoned security is a security that an issuer has already issued. If the issuer wants to sell additional units of a previously issued security, it makes a seasoned offering (sometimes called a secondary offering).
answerFeedback.560c90ca-fb58-46ed-bdad-9041f82d106b: Incorrect because multilateral trading facilities (MTFs) are trading venues that function like exchanges but that do not exercise regulatory authority over their subscribers except with respect to the conduct of their trading in their trading systems.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Equity-Crutu-13
entry.itemBody: In the secondary market, funds flow from:

answerFeedback.77203103-d33d-4efa-af2a-35ad343b7bcd: Incorrect because in the secondary market, funds flow between traders, while in the primary market, funds flow to the issuer of the security from the purchaser (not vice versa).
answerFeedback.afdcedc9-3224-4e2d-bb20-959cf6f14901: Correct because when investors sell securities to others, they trade in the secondary market. In the secondary market, funds flow between traders.
answerFeedback.c3e18f3c-5e6d-449d-a104-333c7a532c47: Incorrect because in the primary (not secondary) market, funds flow to the issuer of the security from the purchaser (investors).

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Equity-Milosevic-15
entry.itemBody: Short sellers are most likely exposed to:

answerFeedback.808709e5-2737-4723-a6c3-b5afa13611d3: Incorrect because the potential gains on a short position are limited to no more than 100 percent whereas the potential losses are unbounded.
answerFeedback.cc8606fb-613a-4f83-a4b8-4fe3fcc20473: Incorrect because the potential gains on a short position are limited to no more than 100 percent whereas the potential losses are unbounded.
answerFeedback.e3f934c7-fd45-4d11-b0e3-f713cad1d378: Correct because short sellers create short positions in securities by borrowing securities from security lenders who are long holders. The short sellers then sell the borrowed securities to other traders. The potential gains on a short position are limited to no more than 100 percent whereas the potential losses are unbounded.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-02845
entry.itemBody: An instruction that indicates when an order may be filled is most likely a(n):

answerFeedback.9f08c54b-e091-4276-865e-0d13f741dc4a: Incorrect because clearing instructions indicate how to arrange the final settlement of the trade, not when the order may be filled.
answerFeedback.d10672a7-4fdb-4e52-af7e-596b1ca76e3e: Incorrect because execution instructions indicate how to fill the order, not when the order may be filled.
answerFeedback.d17d40ec-c83e-40b3-b8d3-0496e3c41466: Correct because validity instructions indicate when the order may be filled.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-01436
entry.itemBody: Broker 1 has a minimum margin requirement of 62.5% and Broker 2 has a maximum leverage ratio of 1.6. The maximum financial leverage possible with Broker 1 is:

answerFeedback.6678957c-978a-439c-81bc-2ae3d205106a: Correct because the maximum financial leverage is the same at both firms given Broker 1's margin requirement and Broker 2's maximum leverage ratio. Leverage Ratio = 100% / margin requirement: Broker 1 leverage ratio = 100% / 62.5% = 1.6 = Broker 2's leverage ratio.
answerFeedback.8da3d640-a3de-4159-86c9-13be30b8eeb4: Incorrect because the leverage ratios with the two brokers are the same at both firms given Broker 1's margin requirement and Broker 2's maximum leverage ratio. Leverage Ratio = 100% / margin requirement: Broker 1 leverage ratio = 100% / 62.5% = 1.6 = Broker 2's leverage ratio.
answerFeedback.aeed3d2e-b646-4c01-9254-f512bbf72654: Incorrect because the leverage ratios with the two brokers are the same at both firms given Broker 1's margin requirement and Broker 2's maximum leverage ratio. Leverage Ratio = 100% / margin requirement: Broker 1 leverage ratio = 100% / 62.5% = 1.6 = Broker 2's leverage ratio.

choices.itemBody: A. less than the maximum financial leverage with Broker 2.
B. equal to the maximum financial leverage with Broker 2.
C. greater than the maximum financial leverage with Broker 2.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-04296
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is most likely used to raise funds for a capital project?

answerFeedback.2893e3f6-04a3-438f-97e9-0e2681ca2faa: Incorrect because issuing a stock dividend would not be an activity the company would do to fund a capital project. Stock dividends are a non-cash form of dividends and the company distributes additional shares of its common stock to shareholders instead of cash. Thus stock dividends will flow to shareholders, not the capital project.
answerFeedback.75824028-fbc0-44bf-9168-66a19443e538: Correct because companies often raise money for projects by selling (issuing) ownership interests (e.g., corporate common stock or partnership interests). Although these equity instruments legally represent ownership in companies rather than loans to the companies, selling equity to raise capital is simply another mechanism for moving money from the future to the present.
answerFeedback.e4105341-cc35-4944-92c9-95dbb319d6eb: Incorrect because issuing a stock dividend would not be an activity the company would do to fund a capital project. Stock dividends are a non-cash form of dividends and the company distributes additional shares of its common stock to shareholders instead of cash. Thus stock dividends will flow to shareholders, not the capital project.

choices.itemBody: C. Both equity issuance and a stock dividend

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-08619
entry.itemBody: Clearing instructions for an order most likely indicate:

answerFeedback.45402163-b8a0-435f-8019-1e0c556af490: Incorrect because validity instructions indicate when the order may be filled.
answerFeedback.8dd29092-273a-4983-9c83-8acd2bcb2945: Incorrect because execution instructions indicate how to fill the order.
answerFeedback.9cd14d71-8ebf-419b-820c-3dc5b2449388: Correct because clearing instructions indicate how to arrange the final settlement of the trade.

choices.itemBody: B. when the order may be filled.
C. how to arrange the settlement of the trade.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06495
entry.itemBody:
A trader observes the following limit order book for a stock:

Bid Size
(Number of Shares)		 Share Price
($)		 Offer Size
(Number of Shares)
10 75.70 ---
20 75.80 ---
--- 75.90 5
--- 76.00 10
--- 76.10 15

If the trader submits an order to buy 20 shares at a limit price of $76.00, the trader's average price per share for this trade based on the current order book will be closest to:

answerFeedback.0a7ec1c1-39e6-48e2-91ef-99d091072b89: Incorrect because this would mistake a bid and an offer by incorrectly concluding that a size/order of 20 corresponds to $75.80.
answerFeedback.5a82c603-a592-4439-9e48-4565cd85ba67: Incorrect because this would neglect that the order is a limit order and calculates the average trade price per unit based on 20 units: (($75.90 × 5) + ($76.00 × 10) + ($76.10 × 5)) / 20 = $76.00.
answerFeedback.9bfdf189-dd8e-4513-ae0a-73f4f407c3fc: Correct because a limit order conveys the instruction to obtain the best price immediately available, but in no event accept a price higher than a specified limit price ($76.00) when buying. That is, 15 units of the stock would trade or execute immediately based on the current order book: 5 units at $75.90 and 10 units at $76.00. The average trade price per unit = ((5 × $75.90) + (10 × $76.00)) / 15 ≈ $75.97.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-03724
entry.itemBody:
A trader buys a stock on margin with the following conditions:

Purchase price per share $50
Equity per share $25
Maintenance margin requirement 25%

If the share price declines, the highest price at which the trader will receive a margin call is closest to:

answerFeedback.3a9a2c7c-bdd3-4916-9196-86eab7878ee3:
Correct because the original equity of $25 indicates a margin loan of $25 ($50 ‒ $25). At a stock price of $33.33, equity will equal $33.33 less the $25 margin loan, or $8.33, which is 25% of the equity per share. $8.33 ⁄ $33.33 ≈ 25%. To reach this answer through calculation, determine where the equity per share equals the 25% margin requirement:

Equity ⁄ Share = (P ‒ L) ⁄ P = maintenance margin;

Where P = Share price and L = Loan amount;

0.25 = (P ‒ $25) ⁄ P; P ≈ $33.33.
answerFeedback.8f416808-7921-4992-9cc5-be0d73b7849a: Incorrect because at a share price of $12.50 and a margin loan of $25, equity will be negative. $12.50 is 25% of the current price of $50 per share.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-07558
entry.itemBody: An investor buys a security on margin posting 50% of the initial price as equity. All else being equal, if the price declines 25%, the investor's new leverage ratio is closest to:

answerFeedback.0de01038-0e1b-4a96-aac6-8ffa7c6e3f22: Incorrect because the amount of the price decline is used instead of the margin to calculate the leverage ratio, 1 ∕ 0.25 = 4.
answerFeedback.8148e005-149a-4066-b2ab-0b1d76dbf0c9:
Correct because the leverage ratio is defined as the ratio of the value of the position to the value of the equity investment in it. The leverage ratio indicates how many times larger a position is than the equity that supports it.

The starting leverage = value ∕equity = 1 ∕ 0.5 = 2

The change in market value is given as 25% decline, implying a new market value of 75%.

With leverage of 2, new equity reduces by 2 × 25% = 50%, 50% × 50% = remaining equity of 25%.

New leverage = new value ∕ new equity = 0.75 ∕ 0.25 = 3.

Expressed alternatively: New leverage = (1 ‒ 0.25) ∕ (0.5 ‒ 0.25) = 3.
answerFeedback.f222507b-8d1c-4728-b069-bb53bcd62a7d: Incorrect because 2 is the starting leverage before the price change, 1/0.5 = 2.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-09644
entry.itemBody: When an investment bank guarantees the sale of an entire issue at a negotiated offering price, this best describes a(n):

answerFeedback.4a1d4827-9cef-4f83-8d09-896b5f5eb023: Incorrect because in a best effort offering, the investment bank acts only as broker. They do not guarantee the sale of the entire issue at a negotiated offering price.
answerFeedback.aeb6f8d5-e31c-4489-aa80-83118eadecd9: Correct because in an underwritten offering—the most common type of offering—the investment bank guarantees the sale of the issue at an offering price that it negotiates with the issuer.
answerFeedback.e16fe7e1-e23d-4070-92e4-0b4649d65e92: Incorrect because corporations can issue new stock via a rights offering. In a rights offering, the corporation distributes rights to buy stock at a fixed price to existing shareholders in proportion to their holdings.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-09425
entry.itemBody: In a well-functioning financial system, changes in asset prices primarily reflect changes in:

answerFeedback.50e569bd-5829-4a3a-ac11-b89a87663d4a: Incorrect because well functioning financial systems are characterized by liquid markets in which the costs of trading are low (operationally efficient markets) and therefore execution costs would not impact asset prices.
answerFeedback.931616e2-01f0-4a40-87ff-675bbb1103d3: Incorrect because well functioning financial systems are characterized by prices that reflect fundamental values so that prices vary primarily in response to changes in fundamental values and not to demands for liquidity made by uninformed traders (informationally efficient markets).
answerFeedback.a9ba4678-9ecc-4b9f-8236-cd238c3be6db: Correct because well functioning financial systems are characterized by prices that reflect fundamental values so that prices vary primarily in response to changes in fundamental values and not to demands for liquidity made by uninformed traders (informationally efficient markets).

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10239
entry.itemBody: If the ability of clients to identify competent agents increases, the need for regulation most likely:

answerFeedback.3f8a9e1e-6f02-4988-9df7-744a52f003ee: Correct because regulation would not be necessary if customers could identify competent agents and effectively measure their performance. Therefore an increase in client ability to identify competent agents would reduce the need for regulation.
answerFeedback.960e1f17-db60-4db6-bb5e-07214ac1922d: Incorrect because the clients' difficulty in identifying competent agents results in a regulatory need. An increase in their ability to select competent agents would reduce this regulatory need.
answerFeedback.e3db7041-9491-4cc8-8426-07636041654a: Incorrect because the clients' difficulty in identifying competent agents results in a regulatory need. An increase in their ability to select competent agents would reduce, not increase, this regulatory need.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10238
entry.itemBody: If the cost to fill trades increases, the market's informational efficiency most likely:

answerFeedback.3b9b7451-6cc6-4226-ba25-e68bde57da02: Incorrect because trading costs do impact informational efficiency: higher costs result in less informed trading and thereby a decrease in efficiency.
answerFeedback.e3c561e5-50ed-48c7-8fd0-8efcf1fa146a: Correct because how accurately prices reflect fundamental information depends on the costs of obtaining fundamental information and on the liquidity available to well-informed traders. If filling orders is very costly, informed trading may not be profitable. In that case, information-motivated traders will not commit resources to collect and analyze data and they will not trade. Without their research and their associated trading, prices would be less informative.
answerFeedback.ec91af16-2e5e-4832-8341-4604af084acb: Incorrect because higher trading costs result in less informed trading and thereby a decrease in efficiency.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-RID-Loo-Equity-003
entry.itemBody: If 1,000 shares of stock purchased at $30 per share on 75% margin are later sold at $26 per share, the return on equity is closest to:

answerFeedback.30757c0a-f8f7-4ca5-b50a-c944b317cf77:
Incorrect because it has incorrectly applied margin requirement and miscalculated the effect of leverage on the return calculation, consequently:

Cost of purchase = Shares purchased × Purchase price = 1,000 × $30 = $30,000

Initial investment = Equity invested = Cost of purchase / Margin requirement

= $30,000 / 75% = $40,000

Proceeds from sale = Shares sold × Sales price = 1,000 × $26 = $26,000

Loss on the position = Proceeds from Sale – Cost of purchase

= $26,000 – $30,000 = –$4,000

Return on investment = Loss on the position / Initial investment

= –$4,000 / $40,000 = 0.1 = 10.00%

Alternatively, it can also be calculated as Return on investment = Loss on the position / Cost of purchase × Margin requirement = –$4,000 / $30,000 × 75% = –10.00%
answerFeedback.ae973fa0-cb4b-4b80-8f22-c7fdcf70a0a2:
Incorrect because it has omitted the margin requirement and the effect of leverage on the return calculation, consequently:

Cost of purchase = Shares purchased × Purchase price = 1,000 × $30 = $30,000

Initial investment = Cost of purchase = $30,000

Proceeds from sale = Shares sold × Sales price = 1,000 × $26 = $26,000

Loss on the position = Proceeds from Sale – Cost of purchase

= $26,000 – $30,000 = –$4,000

Return on investment = Loss on the position / Initial investment

= –$4,000 / $30,000 = –0.1333… ≈ –13.33%
answerFeedback.db37a7ae-c261-499a-884d-bc2e2e3f8eef:
Correct because it has correctly applied margin requirement and calculated the effect of leverage on the return calculation, accordingly:

Cost of purchase = Shares purchased × Purchase price = 1,000 × $30 = $30,000

Initial investment = Equity invested = Cost of purchase × Margin requirement

= $30,000 × 75% = $22,500

Proceeds from sale = Shares sold × Sales price = 1,000 × $26 = $26,000

Loss on the position = Proceeds from Sale – Cost of purchase

= $26,000 – $30,000 = –$4,000

Return on investment = Loss on the position / Initial investment

= –$4,000 / $22,500 = 0.1777… ≈ 17.78%

Alternatively, it can also be calculated as Return on investment = Loss on the position / Cost of purchase / Margin requirement = (–$4,000 / $30,000) / 75% = –0.1777… ≈ –17.78%

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-00656
entry.itemBody: The market structure that uses trade pricing rules to match buyers and sellers is most likely a(n):

answerFeedback.5c5f1da1-67bb-47e8-a0a5-18793c4551ce: Incorrect because in brokered markets, brokers arrange trades between their customers. Brokered markets are common for transactions of unique instruments, such as real estate.  Furthermore, brokers help find traders who are willing to trade when dealers would not be willing to make markets and when traders would not be willing to post orders.
answerFeedback.b3061443-2a4d-43c0-aef5-ac3e8484890b: Correct because order-driven trading systems match buyers to sellers using rules that rank the buy orders and the sell orders based on price, and often along with other secondary criteria.
answerFeedback.e215c5b0-2ef3-4c96-a2d7-5dbcb31889c7: Incorrect because in quote-driven markets, customers trade at the prices quoted by dealers. This is a form of OTC trading. Dealers make markets and are available to supply liquidity.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-00654
entry.itemBody: Which of the following financial intermediaries most likely buy and sell similar instruments at different prices in different markets?

answerFeedback.aa5692e4-41c6-41f9-b997-a95f30012af2: Correct because arbitrageurs buy and sell identical or essentially similar instruments at different prices in different markets.
answerFeedback.c9c30e40-3192-45ff-bc8c-8dc95d7de8fe: Incorrect because brokers are agents who fill orders for their clients. They do not trade with their clients. Instead, they search for traders who are willing to take the other side of their clients' orders. They do not buy and sell, but arrange trades.
answerFeedback.ddc19e1c-8d0e-4795-8a80-f25a0721a5cf: Incorrect because dealers connect a buyer who arrived at one point in time with a seller who arrived at another point in time and by trading with another client on the other side of the market, not buyers and sellers in different markets.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-02092
entry.itemBody: An investor purchases a nondividend-paying stock using 35% margin. If the stock price rises by 7%, the total return on this leveraged position is closest to:

answerFeedback.02f44e2f-bb86-4669-b411-227ab4b08d69: Incorrect because the total return is incorrectly calculated as (1 + margin) × price increase = 1.35 × 7% = 9.45% ≈ 9.5%.
answerFeedback.13efac4a-5819-4bc8-a545-cef387d43fa6: Incorrect because it uses the incorrect leverage ratio, (1 / (1 – 35%)). The incorrect leverage ratio × price increase = (1 / (1 – 35%)) × 7% = 10.76% ≈ 10.8%.
answerFeedback.a3dd3095-f734-4d54-a197-f0b0fb277470: Correct because the leverage ratio is 1 / 35% = 2.86, and the leveraged position return is calculated as the leverage ratio × percentage increase (decrease) in equity = 2.86 × 7% = 20%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-09643
entry.itemBody: An investor purchases stock on margin by posting 25% as equity. If the purchase price was $40 and the sale price was $30, the total return on the leveraged position is closest to:

answerFeedback.14189082-ab7d-4d3e-ae0e-9cf421732a78: Incorrect because it is simply the price decline of the holding: ($30 – $40) / $40 = –0.25 = –25%. This does not account for the leverage of the position.
answerFeedback.43df3120-1b18-4266-bd69-7e91899f2258: Incorrect because it is the percentage change in price / (1 – margin used) = –0.25 / (1 – 0.25) ≈ –0.3333 ≈ –33.33%.
answerFeedback.808f1c88-3e24-4298-92f9-0cfc569d5536: Correct because the maximum leverage ratio associated with a position financed by the minimum margin requirement is one divided by the minimum margin requirement. With a requirement of 25%, the maximum leverage ratio = 100% position / 25% equity = 4.0. The leverage ratio indicates how much more risky a leveraged position is relative to an unleveraged position. The investor's return on the equity investment will be equal to the maximum leverage ratio × change in the stock price. Change in stock price= ($30 – $40) / $40 = –0.25 = –25%. Return on investment = 4 × –25% = 100% loss. Alternatively, initial equity = $40 ×0.25 = $10 per share. With a price decline of $10 ($40 – $30), there is a 100% loss of equity.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-RID-Elliott-Equity-003
entry.itemBody: The maximum initial leverage ratio associated with a position financed by margin is one divided by:

answerFeedback.ad2ffe6c-4225-4cf0-b1d0-9b768fdf91d2: Incorrect because the maximum leverage ratio associated with a position financed by the minimum margin requirement is one divided by the minimum margin requirement.
answerFeedback.be8ccf44-ccf9-4391-83b6-e24a33658c1c: Correct because the maximum leverage ratio associated with a position financed by the minimum margin requirement is one divided by the minimum margin requirement.
answerFeedback.d1ada773-9d40-41bd-aaed-48be0ceb8125: Incorrect because the maximum leverage ratio associated with a position financed by the minimum margin requirement is one divided by the minimum margin requirement.

choices.itemBody: A. To regulate arbitrageurs’ profits (excess returns).

Thus, warrants are typically classified as equity and are least likely to be a part of a fixed-income mutual fund. Commercial paper and repurchase agreements are short-term fixed-income securities.

As opposed to a futures contract, trading out of a forward contract is quite difficult. There is no exchange of cash at the origination of a forward contract. There is no exchange on a forward contract until the maturity of the contract.

feedback.neutral: B is correct. The holder of the call option will exercise the call options if the price is above the exercise price of $305 per share. Note that if the stock price is above $305 but less than $308, the option would be exercised even though the net result for the option buyer after considering the premium is a loss. For example, if the stock price is $307, the option buyer would exercise the option to make $2 = $307 – $305 per share, resulting in a loss of $1 = $3 – $2 after considering the premium. It is better to exercise and have a loss of only $1, however, rather than not exercise and lose the entire $3 premium.

C is correct. The return is 50 percent. If the position had been unleveraged, the return would be 20% = (60 – 50)/50. Because of leverage, the return is 50% = 2.5 × 20%.

Another way to look at this problem is that the equity contributed by the trader (the minimum margin requirement) is 40% = 100% ÷ 2.5. The trader contributed $20 = 40% of $50 per share. The gain is $10 per share, resulting in a return of 50% = 10/20.

entry.title: CFA0161-Q21

feedback.neutral:
B is correct. The return is –15.4 percent.

  • Total cost of the purchase = $16,000 = 500 × $32

  • Equity invested = $12,000 = 0.75 × $16,000

  • Amount borrowed = $4,000 = 16,000 – 12,000

  • Interest paid at month end = $80 = 0.02 × $4,000

  • Dividend received at month end = $250 = 500 × $0.50

  • Proceeds on stock sale = $14,000 = 500 × $28

  • Total commissions paid = $20 = $10 + $10

  • Net gain/loss = −$1,850 = −16,000 − 80 + 250 + 14,000 − 20

  • Initial investment including commission on purchase = $12,010

  • Return = −15.4% = −$1,850/$12,010

entry.title: CFA0161-Q23

feedback.neutral:
B is correct. A margin call will first occur at a price of $17.86. Because you have contributed half and borrowed the remaining half, your initial equity is 50 percent of the initial stock price, or $12.50 = 0.50 × $25. If P is the subsequent price, your equity would change by an amount equal to the change in price. So, your equity at price P would be 12.50 + (P – 25). A margin call will occur when the percentage margin drops to 30 percent. So, the price at which a margin call will occur is the solution to the following equation.

Equity/Share Price/Share = 12.50 + P − 25 P = 30 %

The solution is P = $17.86.

entry.title: CFA0161-Q33

feedback.neutral: C is correct. Order III (time of arrival of 9:53:04) has precedence. In the order precedence hierarchy, the first rule is price priority. Based on this rule, sell orders II, III, and IV get precedence over order I. The next rule is display precedence at a given price. Because order II is a hidden order, orders III and IV get precedence. Finally, order III gets precedence over order IV based on time priority at same price and same display status.

(€)		 Special Instruction
(If any)
I 9:52:01 20.33  
II 9:52:08 20.29 Hidden order
III 9:53:04 20.29  
IV 9:53:49 20.29

choices.itemBody: A. Order I (time of arrival of 9:52:01).
B. Order II (time of arrival of 9:52:08).
C. Order III (time of arrival of 9:53:04).

entry.title: CFA0161-Q34

feedback.neutral: C is correct. The order for 500 shares would get cancelled; there would be no fill. Li is willing to buy at CNY 74.25 or less but the minimum offer price in the book is CNY 74.30; therefore, no part of the order would be filled. Because Li’s order is immediate-or-cancel, it would be cancelled.

entry.itemBody: Zhenhu Li has submitted an immediate-or-cancel buy order for 500 shares of a company at a limit price of CNY 74.25. There are two sell limit orders standing in that stock’s order book at that time. One is for 300 shares at a limit price of CNY 74.30 and the other is for 400 shares at a limit price of CNY 74.35. How many shares in Li’s order would get cancelled?

choices.itemBody: A. None (the order would remain open but unfilled).

entry.title: CFA0161-Q35

feedback.neutral:
B is correct. Ian’s average trade price is:

£ 19.92 = 300 × £ 20.02 + 400 × £ 19.89   +   200 × £ 19.84 300 + 400 + 200

Ian’s sell order first fills with the most aggressively priced buy order, which is Mary’s order for 300 shares at £20.02. Ian still has 700 shares for sale. The next most aggressively priced buy order is Ann’s order for 400 shares at £19.89. This order is filled. Ian still has 300 shares for sale. The next most aggressively priced buy order is Paul’s order for 200 shares at £19.84. A third trade takes place. Ian still has 100 shares for sale.

The next buy order is Keith’s order for 1,000 shares at £19.70. However, this price is below Ian’s limit price of £19.83. Therefore, no more trade is possible.

entry.itemBody:
A market has the following limit orders standing on its book for a particular stock:

Buyer Bid Size
(Number of Shares)		 Limit Price (£) Offer Size
(Number of Shares)		 Seller
Keith 1,000 19.70    
Paul 200 19.84    
Ann 400 19.89    
Mary 300 20.02    
    20.03 800 Jack
    20.11 1,100 Margaret
    20.16 400 Jeff

 

Ian submits a day order to sell 1,000 shares, limit £19.83. Assuming that no more buy orders are submitted on that day after Ian submits his order, what would be Ian’s average trade price?

entry.title: CFA0161-Q36

feedback.neutral: C is correct. In such a market, well-informed traders will find it easy to trade and their trading will make the market more informationally efficient. In a liquid market, it is easier for informed traders to fill their orders. Their trading will cause prices to incorporate their information and the prices will be more in line with the fundamental values.

entry.itemBody: A financial analyst is examining whether a country’s financial market is well functioning. She finds that the transaction costs in this market are low and trading volumes are high. She concludes that the market is quite liquid. In such a market:

choices.itemBody: A. traders will find it hard to make use of their information.
B. traders will find it easy to trade and their trading will make the market less informationally efficient.
C. traders will find it easy to trade and their trading will make the market more informationally efficient.

entry.title: CFA0161-Q37

feedback.neutral: C is correct. Ensure that investors in the stock market achieve a rate of return that is at least equal to the risk-free rate of return is least likely to be included as an objective of market regulation. Stocks are risky investments and there would be occasions when a stock market investment would not only have a return less than the risk-free rate but also a negative return. Minimizing agency costs and ensuring that financial markets are fair and orderly are objectives of market regulation.

entry.itemBody: The government of a country whose financial markets are in an early stage of development has hired you as a consultant on financial market regulation. Your first task is to prepare a list of the objectives of market regulation. Which of the following is least likely to be included in this list of objectives?

choices.itemBody: A. Minimize agency problems in the financial markets.
B. Ensure that financial markets are fair and orderly.
C. Ensure that investors in the stock market achieve a rate of return that is at least equal to the risk-free rate of return.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516016
entry.itemBody: A pension fund has decided to invest in alternative investments. Which of the following assets is the fund most likely to include in this strategy?

answerFeedback.09b769e0-0fc1-4c6e-aca1-453ca89d8c8e: Incorrect. Equity exchange-traded funds are traditional not alternative investments.
answerFeedback.ac4c5ed6-2a9d-4df5-9934-2317f174d013: Incorrect. Convertible bonds are traditional, not alternative, investments.
answerFeedback.df82a962-b176-46f5-b1a4-4a5cea0babbc: Correct. Securitized debt is an alternative investment, so it could be included in this strategy.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516017
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements is most accurate concerning a short position of 100 shares of a stock at $50 per share?

answerFeedback.1900c847-9b75-4ab5-af78-834ce71771c3: Correct. The potential gains on a short position are limited to no more than 100%; the potential losses are unbounded. The lowest market price per share an investor can repurchase the stock to return to the security’s lender is $0, so the maximum gain is ($50 – $0) × 100 = $5,000.
answerFeedback.35874f23-dcda-42f0-b92f-81e2baf6e7b1: Incorrect. The potential gains on a short position are limited to no more than 100%: ($50 – $0) × 100 = $5,000.
answerFeedback.6555618b-5aa2-483e-bebe-ff56db8e707c: Incorrect. The potential losses are unbounded because the market price that an investor can repurchase the stock to return to the security’s lender can go up with no limit. If the stock goes from $50 to $135 per share the loss would be $8,500.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516018
entry.itemBody: A Japanese exporter will sell US dollars for Japanese yen in the quote-driven currency markets. Which of the following statements best describes her currency exchange transactions?

answerFeedback.93f13b4d-d739-4fab-9afc-bb7a6a009832: Incorrect. In the quote-driven currency markets, currency exchange transactions take place in the over-the-counter, not organized, exchanges.
answerFeedback.a0d7748d-a419-4867-8de1-098bc6824347: Incorrect. A Japanese exporter pays no fee or commission to dealers. Dealers will profit from the bid–ask spreads.
answerFeedback.b1196442-36a2-4281-a7f1-10e69994ec9f: Correct. In the quote-driven currency markets, dealers are counterparties to currency exchange transactions.

choices.itemBody: B. She will pay commissions for exchange services.
C. This currency exchange transaction takes place in organized exchanges.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516045
entry.itemBody: Forward contracts are most likely to be attractive hedging vehicles to investors who:

answerFeedback.3e62a4b6-dc51-4af1-b756-d79178e1bab5: Incorrect. Forward contracts are custom agreements that depend on each counterparty’s knowledge of the creditworthiness of the other.
answerFeedback.57bd1fce-cde6-45b1-985b-29013607398c: Correct. Most forward contracts do not require an upfront cash outlay. Other hedging vehicles, such as futures (which require margin accounts) and options (which must be purchased for a fee), do require upfront payments.
answerFeedback.a2885c0c-a092-43f5-9583-d5d07fade9b5: Incorrect. Because forward contracts are custom agreements, it is difficult to find another party who is both willing to take over the contract obligations and acceptable to the existing counterparty. Futures would be more suitable in this circumstance because they can be closed out early.

choices.itemBody: A. do not want to make an upfront outlay of cash.
B. want to reserve the right to close out their position early.
C. are not in a position to investigate the creditworthiness of their counterparties.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516032
entry.itemBody:
An investor buys a stock on margin. Assume that the interest on the loan and the dividend are both paid at the end of the holding period. The data related to the transaction are as follows:

Number of shares 500
Purchase price per share $28
Leverage ratio 3.33
Commission $0.05/share
Position holding period Six months
Sale price per share $30
Call money rate 5% per year
Dividend $0.40/share

The investor’s total return on this investment over the margin holding period is closest to:

answerFeedback.5631d2d4-ecfc-4d85-8d66-2959995c679f:
Incorrect. It computes margin interest for the entire year, not six months.

Initial investment [($28 × 500) × (1/3.33)] + ($0.05 × 500) $4,229
– Purchase commission $0.05 × 500 –25
+ Trading gain ($30 – $28) × 500 1,000
– Margin interest paid $9,800 × 0.05 –490
+ Dividends received $0.40 × 500 200
– Sales commission paid $0.05 × 500 –25
= Remaining equity --- $4,889
Return on investment ($4,889 – $4,229)/$4,229 15.6%
answerFeedback.715d9b81-e87e-4dc6-8bf1-a1cb6dd7cb60:
Correct.

Initial investment [($28 × 500) × (1/3.33)] + ($0.05 × 500) $4,229
– Purchase commission $0.05 × 500 –25
+ Trading gain ($30 – $28) × 500 1,000
– Margin interest paid $9,800 × 0.05 × 6 months –245
+ Dividends received $0.40 × 500 200
– Sales commission paid $0.05 × 500 –25
= Remaining equity --- $5,134
Return on investment ($5,134 – $4,229)/$4,229 21.4%
answerFeedback.fe818601-15c2-4f26-a1fc-254b339f976a:
Incorrect. It ignores the dividend received during the margin period.

Initial investment [($28 × 500) × (1/3.33)] + ($0.05 × 500) $4,229
– Purchase commission $0.05 × 500 –25
+ Trading gain ($30 – $28) × 500 1,000
– Margin interest paid $9,800 × 0.05 × 6 months –245
+ Dividends received --- 0
– Sales commission paid $0.05 × 500 –25
= Remaining equity --- $4,934
Return on investment ($4,934 – $4,229)/$4,229 16.7%

entry.title: ITEM_20170516097
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is most likely a primary market transaction?

answerFeedback.10ff1ab1-3768-44ff-b2f5-091db6a5dbd4: Incorrect. Market order sales take place in secondary markets.
answerFeedback.41bd3a8b-d9f1-4809-944f-e92d00599280: Incorrect. The exercise of an exchange-traded call option is a secondary market transaction involving the purchase by option owner of previously issued security.
answerFeedback.fbee3878-2fb6-4236-8a13-e86b5b529346: Correct. Private placements qualify as primary market transactions because they are sales of securities by issuers directly to a small group of qualified investors.

choices.itemBody: B. A market order sale of bonds
C. The exercise of an exchange-traded call option

entry.title: ITEM_20170516009
entry.itemBody: A stop-buy order is most likely placed when a trader:

answerFeedback.042201aa-5c32-4d85-9cad-5ca63438973c: Incorrect. A stop-sell order is appropriate when the trader holds a long position, not short position. A stop-sell order becomes valid when the stock price falls.
answerFeedback.67cb3205-833c-4812-8673-b5c43eb2cf17: Incorrect. A stop-buy order is beneficial when the stock is undervalued (not overvalued) but the trader is unwilling to trade without market confirmation.
answerFeedback.702a8005-ea27-4bf0-a95b-24b1b75b101b: Correct. A trader who has entered into a short sale will incur losses if the stock price begins to increase. A stop-buy order helps limit the loss on a short position because it becomes valid for execution when the stock price rises above the specified stop price.

choices.itemBody: A. thinks that the stock is overvalued.
B. wants to limit the loss on a long position.
C. wants to limit the loss on a short position.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516015
entry.itemBody: The economic equilibrium interest rate in a well-functioning financial system is most likely determined by:

answerFeedback.0e316e10-608f-4dc6-af1b-ac8fd3c2e26a: Incorrect. Time consumption preferences of borrowers are a specific example impacting the demand of money, but they do not address the supply of money.
answerFeedback.856f6599-61a7-452e-ae9c-2389ceeea97f: Correct. The economic equilibrium interest rate in a well-functioning financial system is determined by the aggregate supply and demand of money. An expected rate of return exists, in theory, in which the aggregate supply of funds for investing and the aggregate demand for funds through borrowing and equity issuing are equal.
answerFeedback.f3e36d27-a6f3-4e78-8e0e-9d7b664265d4: Incorrect. Central bank policy is a specific example impacting the supply of money, but it does not address the demand of money.

choices.itemBody: B. the supply and demand of money.
C. the time consumption preferences of borrowers.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516019
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements concerning the objectives of market regulation is least accurate?

answerFeedback.36787e82-92dd-445d-ac53-0abf1ce1219d: Incorrect. One of the objectives of market regulation is to promote fair and orderly markets in which traders can trade at prices that accurately reflect fundamental values.
answerFeedback.510aca62-162b-4b72-be81-aa6bcea37613: Correct. Regulators help solve agency problems by setting minimum standards of competence, not skill, for agents and by defining and enforcing minimum standards of practice.
answerFeedback.68a93ba9-273e-4273-b3b6-eb2882162c69: Incorrect. Regulators ensure that systems are in place to protect customers from fraud.

choices.itemBody: A. Regulators promote fair and orderly markets.
B. ensure that systems are in place to prevent fraud.
C. Regulators set standards to ensure that all agents acting in the market are skilled.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516022
entry.itemBody: A trader who owns shares of a stock currently trading at $100 per share places a “GTC, stop $90, limit $85 sell” order (GTC means good till cancelled). Assuming the specified stop condition is satisfied and the order becomes executed, which of the following statements is most accurate?

answerFeedback.51132368-915a-434b-b4ad-872ad9633cf6: Incorrect. The order can be executed at any prices between $85 and $90.
answerFeedback.776b2f04-2256-4e31-8761-c42bf2a4f186: Incorrect. The order becomes invalid for execution when the price falls below $85.
answerFeedback.c4cfc8ef-5c64-494f-a495-f826fcaced6e: Correct. The order becomes valid when the price falls to, or below, $90. The “limit $85 sell” indicates that the trader is unwilling to sell below $85. Thus, the trader faces a maximum loss of $15 ($100 – $85).

choices.itemBody: A. The order will be executed at either $90 or $85.
B. The trader faces a maximum realized loss of $15.
C. The order becomes a market order when the price falls below $85 and remains valid for execution.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516025
entry.itemBody: A trader places a limit order to buy shares at a price of $49.94 with the stock trading at a market bid price of $49.49 and the bid–ask spread of 0.7%. The order will most likely be filled at:

answerFeedback.54c8d6a0-72c7-4cc7-995d-923f741d825e: Incorrect. The trader can only sell (not buy) at the market bid price. He has to buy at the market ask price.
answerFeedback.82777b7e-9968-4cc0-9b17-d8d73f7943e2: Incorrect. The order limit of $49.94 is larger than the market ask price and accordingly the order will be filled at the market ask price (i.e., $49.84) and not the limit order price.
answerFeedback.8fc229f8-9e24-49b2-a225-370cf180dac0: Correct. An order is filled at the best available price as long as this price is lower than the limit price. In this case, the best available price is the market ask price = $49.49 × (1 + 0.7%) = $49.84. Because this price is lower than the limit price of $49.94, the order will be filled at this price.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516027
entry.itemBody:
The following data pertain to a margin purchase of a stock:

Purchase price $50/share
Sale price $55/share
Shares purchased 500
Margin 45%
Call money rate 6%
Dividend $1.80/share
Commission on purchase and sale $0.05/share
If the stock is sold exactly one year after the purchase, the total return on this investment is closest to:

answerFeedback.14cee557-93c8-4bf0-8be3-fb9f077c2e76:
Correct.

Proceeds on sale $55 × 500 $27,500
Minus payoff loan $50 × 500 × 0.55 –$13,750
Minus margin interest paid $13,750 × 0.06 –$825
Plus dividend received $1.80 × 500 $900
Minus sales commission paid on sale $0.05 × 500 –$25
= Remaining equity --- $13,800
Initial Investment (including commission) ($50 × 500 × 0.45) + ($0.05 × 500) $11,275
Return on the initial investment: ($13,800 – $11,275)/$11,275 22.4%
answerFeedback.1aafdbdb-59b4-465e-a3f8-5758edc3ad21:
Incorrect. It ignores the dividend received.

Proceeds on sale: $55 × 500 $27,500
Payoff loan: $50 × 500 × 0.55 –$13,750
Margin interest paid: $13,750 × 0.06 –$825
Dividend received: $1.80 × 500 Ignored
Sales commission paid: $0.05 × 500 –$25
Remaining equity $12,900
Initial Investment: ($50 × 500 × 0.45) + ($0.05 × 500) $11,275
Return on the initial investment: ($12,900 – $11,275)/$11,275 14.4%
answerFeedback.a56b01da-abc0-4c8e-bb46-a314e3292c21:
Incorrect. It switches the percentages between margin and loan.

Proceeds on sale: $55 × 500 $27,500
Payoff loan: $50 × 500 × 0.45 –$11,250
Margin interest paid: $11,250 × 0.06 –$675
Dividend received: $1.80 × 500 $900
Sales commission paid: $0.05 × 500 –$25
Remaining equity $16,450
Initial Investment: ($50 × 500 × 0.55) + ($0.05 × 500) $13,775
Return on the initial investment: ($16,450 – $13,775)/$13,775 19.4%

entry.title: ITEM_20170516028
entry.itemBody: A trader buys a stock at $64 on margin with a leverage ratio of 2.5 and a maintenance margin of 30%. Below what price will a margin call most likely occur?

answerFeedback.8452fed6-2cca-41b9-8421-dfb70d7cbbea:
Incorrect. Mistakes 60% as initial equity.

Initial equity = $64 × 0.6 = $38.40

$38.40+P−$64 P =30%

P = $36.57
answerFeedback.92f7a1a7-0942-4519-ab19-14e836a617d7: Incorrect. Simply takes 70% of the original purchase price by mistaking (1 – maintenance margin %) to be equal to the critical price for margin call = 64 × 0.7 = $44.80.
answerFeedback.aeebaae1-afaf-40d1-9cbb-a985378051e7:
Correct.

Equity = 1 Leverage ratio = 1 2.5 =0.4

Initial equity = $64 × 0.4 = $25.60

Critical “P” for margin call = Equity Share ÷ Price Share = $25.60+P−$64 P =30%

P = $54.86

Alternate solution:

Debit balance 1−maintenance margin% = 64×0.6 1−0.3 =$54.86

entry.title: ITEM_20170516029
entry.itemBody: A trader buys a stock at $30 and wants to limit downside risk. Which of the following orders will most likely guarantee that he can sell the stock at $25?

answerFeedback.193e930c-bf1a-4d01-9c7f-30fd30084f9d: Incorrect. A “GTC, stop $25, limit $25 sell” order limits the lower boundary to $25 but it does not guarantee execution at $25; in a fast-moving market prices may have dropped below the limit and the order will then not be executed.
answerFeedback.e9dff524-7115-4702-8f94-fa56f256b1ff: Incorrect. A “GTC, stop $25, market sell” order becomes a market order when the price drops to or below $25 and is executed at the best price available in the market. Thus, the selling price of $25 is not guaranteed.
answerFeedback.ee34d0f3-28b8-43b1-8fc1-6a4fac0fd56c: Correct. Option contracts can be viewed as limit orders for which execution is guaranteed at the strike price. Therefore, a put buy order at a strike price of $25 will guarantee selling the stock at $25.

choices.itemBody: A. Put option buy market order with a strike price of $25
B. GTC (good till canceled), stop $25, market sell order
C. GTC (good till canceled), stop $25, limit $25 sell order

entry.title: ITEM_20170516033
entry.itemBody: The type of efficiency that exists in an economy that distributes capital in the most productive way is best described as:

answerFeedback.3578be66-9ddf-475c-afce-56d2f05b43d6: Incorrect. An operationally efficient financial system is one in which the costs of arranging trades are low.
answerFeedback.774a35d4-3fc4-46dc-b7ea-83d34cc61c3a: Correct. Economies are said to be allocationally efficient when their financial systems allocate capital (funds) to those uses that are most productive.
answerFeedback.f3dfdbb9-47f9-496e-9530-74fb13787c4f: Incorrect. An informationally efficient financial system is one in which the prices of assets and contracts reflect all available information related to their fundamental values.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516043
entry.itemBody: A university endowment fund is mandated to hold some of its value in alternative investments. Which of the following would most likely be included in the fund’s alternative investments portfolio?

answerFeedback.107f5c4c-725e-4513-8a96-cdb558b1015c: Incorrect. Exchange-traded funds are publicly traded and do not qualify as alternative investments
answerFeedback.dac225ab-9078-4477-9d3f-6e559a7921a3: Incorrect. Convertible preferred shares may be publicly traded and do not qualify as alternative investments.
answerFeedback.fdad1f58-5d4d-4e34-adeb-e020e7920ca7: Correct. Real estate securities qualify as alternative investments.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516044
entry.itemBody: When parties exchange fixed cash payments for payments that depend on the returns to a stock or a stock index, they are purchasing a(n):

answerFeedback.3f0bbc94-60ed-4052-a33b-bc674d4337d5: Correct. Equity swaps consist of parties exchanging fixed cash payments for payments that depend on the returns to a stock or a stock index.
answerFeedback.6aea87a9-a102-4e98-8a4a-a343648b7773: Incorrect. The payments depend on the returns to a stock or a stock index, but an index fund has not been directly purchased.
answerFeedback.6ba24540-3483-4b8f-9350-850614c01444: Incorrect. An option contract allows the holder (the purchaser) of the option to buy or sell an underlying instrument at a specified price at or before a specified date in the future.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516047
entry.itemBody: Dark pools are best described as:

answerFeedback.64c57a08-0de9-4030-8f12-94ba05a841aa: Correct. Dark pools are trading venues that function like exchanges but do not exercise regulatory authority over their subscribers except with respect to the conduct of their trading in those venues.
answerFeedback.69f8c4c6-536e-42c0-bc8c-fcb638929f10: Incorrect. Dark pools may be operated by investment dealers but do not necessarily trade high risk securities.
answerFeedback.7b2e3ed0-8833-4531-907f-2f4482dc0cc6: Incorrect. This is the definition of pooled investment vehicles.

choices.itemBody: A. operated by investment dealers that specialize in high-risk securities.
B. trading venues that exercise little regulatory authority over their subscribers.
C. certain groups of similar assets that issue securities representing shared ownership.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-RID-Elliott-Equity-002
entry.itemBody: For a security position purchased on margin, the leverage ratio is the ratio of the value of the position to:

answerFeedback.97969329-1ca8-4669-b603-bb9c3ff3950e: Correct because the leverage ratio is the ratio of the value of the position to the value of the equity investment in it.
answerFeedback.a59b7516-5b47-401d-a379-f43be8d9487f: Incorrect because the leverage ratio is the ratio of the value of the position to the value of the equity investment in it.
answerFeedback.e0f1ab2d-5f7c-4997-8a23-afd89d03ac92: Incorrect because the leverage ratio is the ratio of the value of the position to the value of the equity investment in it.

choices.itemBody: A. the value of equity in the position.
B. the amount of the margin loan in the position.
C. the amount of the margin loan plus equity in the position.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-01681
entry.itemBody: If it is difficult to find a buyer or a seller for an asset, the asset most likely trades on:

answerFeedback.2db117de-bd2a-4126-a7ea-b539181dba28: Correct because brokered markets are markets in which brokers arrange trades among their clients. Brokers organize markets for instruments for which finding a buyer or seller willing to trade is difficult because the instruments are unique.
answerFeedback.85757331-a76c-4a56-9d66-03845999dbe5: Incorrect because organizing order-driven markets for these instruments (assets for which finding a buyer or seller is difficult) is not sensible because too few traders would submit orders for them.
answerFeedback.f9197201-8da8-4a02-96c9-69a67014cd6b: Incorrect because dealers generally are unable or unwilling to hold these assets in their inventories, they will not make markets in them.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-11012
entry.itemBody:
An investor purchases 1,000 shares of a non-dividend paying stock on margin and sells them after one year as follows:

Purchase price per share $25
Sale price per share $20
Annual call money rate 5%
Leverage ratio 2

Ignoring commissions, the investor's holding period return is closest to:

answerFeedback.1ea1c644-663a-4101-be75-ed96e6cc0751:
Correct because this is the return on investment to the investor.

Total purchase price = $25/share × 1,000 shares = $25,000

Leverage ratio of 2 indicates buyer's equity of 1/2

Buyer's equity = 1/2 × $25,000 = $12,500

Borrowed money = $25,000 – $12,500 = $12,500

Interest on borrowed money = 5% × $12,500 = $625

Sale proceeds = $20/share × 1,000 shares = $20,000

Net return to buyer = Sale proceeds – purchase price – interest payment = $20,000 – $25,000 – $625 = –$5,625

Return on investment to the buyer = –$5,625 / $12,500 = –45%
answerFeedback.5631d718-2839-4cbf-a522-8f19bf787bda:
Incorrect because in determining the return to the investor, cost of borrowing is not taken into account.

($20,000 – $25,000)/$12,500 = –40%
answerFeedback.7ada86f2-831a-4f15-937f-8f46054cb7a3:
Incorrect because this is the return on purchase value ignoring leverage.

($20,000 – $625 – $25,000)/$25,000 = –22.5%

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10074
entry.itemBody: A trader uses margin to purchase a stock for $50 by posting 30% equity. If the first margin call occurs when the price falls below $43.75, the maintenance margin requirement is closest to:

answerFeedback.c5845b18-529d-4ad9-89ef-95272a2516c4: Correct because the margin requirement is equity per share / price per share: = (Initial equity + actual price – initial price) / (actual price) = (15+43.75 – 50) / 43.75 = 20%.
answerFeedback.f57fae55-8610-4de9-8793-2cb81a6eb8e5: Incorrect because it uses the relative change in stock price as the margin requirement. Margin requirement = (50 – 43.75) / 50 = 12.5% ≈ 13%.
answerFeedback.f58d4ddd-2c40-43bb-b867-0c664504d676: Incorrect because it divides by the initial price instead of the last price. (Initial equity + actual price - initial price)/ (initial price) = (15 + 43.75 – 50)/50 = 17.5% ≈ 18%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06972
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a stock purchased on margin:

Initial margin posted as equity 45%
Initial stock price $15.00
Maintenance margin 25%

The price below which a margin call will first occur is closest to:

answerFeedback.80742bf0-4603-48c8-bc2d-c64bbabe9030: Incorrect because the initial equity is incorrectly computed as (1 – 0.45) × $15 = $8.25. Substituting, P = ($15 – $8.25) / (1 – 0.25) = $6.75/0.75 = $9.00.
answerFeedback.d03e08c6-d347-41cd-a8a7-0b0561fe8077: Correct because the price, P, below which a margin call will take place is the solution to the following equation: maintenance margin requirement = (initial equity + P – initial stock price)/P. Rearranging the equation, P = (initial stock price – initial equity) / (1 – maintenance margin requirement). The initial margin requirement is the minimum fraction of the purchase price that must be trader's equity. Initial equity = 0.45 × $15 = $6.75. Substituting, P = ($15 – $6.75) / (1 – 0.25) = $8.25/0.75 = $11.00. Therefore, at a price below $11.00 a margin call will be made.
answerFeedback.df9676cb-28b1-4393-996b-4fa5f494792d: Incorrect because it is (1 – maintenance margin requirement) × initial stock price = (1 – 0.25) × $15 = 0.75 × $15 = $11.25.
